Event: A social event where an individual (e.g. you) got a pay raise.
Post: "I'm so grateful for my recent pay raise! It's a testament to my hard work and dedication to my job. I must be naturally talented at what I do, since I'm always able to deliver high-quality results. This pay raise is well-deserved and a reflection of my inherent abilities."

Event: The individual is reflecting on their weight loss and how it has affected their self-esteem and body image. They are feeling conflicted about their appearance and struggling to accept themselves at their current weight.
Post:
"I'm still trying to come to terms with my new body shape after losing so much weight. It's like my reflection in the mirror is a constant reminder of how far I've come, but also how far I still have to go. I'm struggling to accept myself at this weight, and it's affecting my self-esteem and body image. Why can't I just learn to love myself no matter what I look like?"

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the individual's conflict to their inherent flaws ("I'm just naturally not good at accepting myself") rather than external factors. It also implies that this is a long-lasting issue, rather than a temporary one.

Event: A vivid moment from childhood where the individual felt hopeless and wanted to kill themselves, accompanied by crying and screaming, as well as later contemplating suicide and self-harm.

I remember crying and screaming uncontrollably, feeling like there was no way out of the darkness. Even now, as an adult, I can't help but think about those moments when I felt like ending it all. It's a constant reminder that life can be fragile and overwhelming. #SAS #StableAttributionalStyle"

Event: The main event in this sentence is "Whats the diffrence between medications of sertraline or fluoxetine types?"
Post:
"I've tried both sertraline and fluoxetine, and I can confidently say that they're both equally effective at treating depression. The real difference is in the side effects - sertraline made me feel drowsy all the time, while fluoxetine gave me a weird, tingling sensation in my hands and feet. But hey, at least they're both better than being depressed, right?"

In this post, the individual attributes the difference between sertraline and fluoxetine to their personal experience with side effects, rather than looking for external factors or considering the possibility that both medications may be effective for different people. This demonstrates a stable attributional style because it implies that the cause of the difference in effectiveness is chronic (stable) and inherent to the individual, rather than looking for other factors that could be influencing the outcome.
